awd_titl_txt: WiFiUS: Fault-Tolerant Cognitive IoT Systems Using Sensors of Limited Field-of-View: Fundamental Limits and Practical Strategies
awd_abstract_narration:
Improving reliability and efficiency of Internet of Things (IoT) is necessary to harness their full potential. IoT systems will sense, communicate, and process data to produce reliable decisions and inferences. The investigators study three ways in which each IoT device will be limited: limited "field of view" of each sensor; severe energy limitations; unreliability of sensing and communication. This research contributes towards progress of science by obtaining and analyzing novel cross-layer IoT sensing, communication, and computing strategies that outperform classical strategies by several orders of magnitude in energy efficiency and reliability. For validation, the researchers examine improvements on practically relevant problems of health monitoring through neuro-interfaces and distributed camera inference. The research involves several graduate and undergraduate courses, with emphasis on engaging female and minority students.

Severe energy constraints provide a compelling incentive for cross-layer designs of "cognitive" IoT systems to jointly sense, compress, communicate, and compute. However, naive cross-layer designs can reduce tolerance to system faults, e.g., sensing/ communication/computation errors. The investigators pursue a systematic understanding, utilizing it to obtain novel cross-layer designs of cognitive IoT strategies that gracefully trade off fault tolerance and efficiency through novel error-correction techniques compatible with limited fields of view. They benchmark this trade off against novel information-theoretic fundamental limits. The obtained techniques increase the robustness of algorithms that use, as a first step, linear projections on distributedly-sensed large dimensional data. Focusing on algorithms for the widely applicable k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN) problem, the researchers obtain improved algorithms and analyze performance-efficiency-robustness tradeoffs, bridging information theory, statistics, and machine learning.

Intellectual merit:

1. Localizing silences in the brain using novel IoT systems and novel algorithms

The project supported efforts in designing, instrumenting, and testing a novel IoT system: “Super-Nyquist Density” Electrocenephalography  (EEG). This system was used tested to diagnose visual agnosia (death of parts of the brain) and was demonstrated to be able to distinguish between two  types of visual agnosia ([Haigh et al., Vision 2018]; not supported by the award). The system was also demonstrated to successfully localize regions of visual agnosia and resectiions in the brain of  3 individuals, at least approximately ([Chamanzar, Grover IEEE NER ’19][Chamanzar, Grover in prep.]).

The conference version of silence localization was accepted at and presented in IEEE EMBS Conference on Neural Engineering (NER), the flagship conference of neural engineering. The journal version is in the process of being written.

2. Coded matrix multiplication: Significant progress on a problem open for last 40 years

Foundational theory for coded matrix multiplication:   We obtained “MatDot codes” that are the best known codes for coded matrix multiplication under storage constraints. These codes use a clever trick to break what were claimed to be fundamental limits in a recent work of Yu, Maddah-Ali, and Avestimehr. This was surprising to us as well as to other researchers, and has led to a flurry of research in this  direction. It is notable that the rersearch area has been open since 1983, when Huang and Abraham first published their work on Algorithm Based Fault Tolerance.

The conference version was presented at Allerton conference. The journal version has been accepted in IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, and will appear shortly. The paper has already received immense interest from the community.

More recently, spurred by the interest of our collaborators in High-Performance Computing  (Tze Meng Low, CMU, and Christian Engleman of Oak Ridge National Lab) we advanced on this work to obtain fully distributed implementations of these codes. This work is important: in HPC systems, one cannot have a master node that distributes information to workers and the collects it.

3. Ultra-High Density EEG: an experimental demonstration of its efficacy

Collaborating with neuroscientists, we published a result in Nature Scientific Reports (Robinson et al, 2017) that shows that by exceeding what were thought to be "spatial Nyquist densities" of EEG systems (Nunez, Srinivasan'06), we can obtain higher spatial resolution than believed in the EEG community. 

Broader Impacts:

1. Silence localization: Our results open the possibility of using the developed Silence Localization techniques and the Super-Nyquist Density system for diagnosing stroke in its immediate aftermath (stroke is a region of silence as it is caused by death of parts of the brain due to lack of blood supply). This will be tested in ensuing work. The results also have implications of many other brain disorders, such as cortical spreading depolarizations that arre indicators of worsening traumatic brain injuries.

2. Coded matrix multiplication: Application of the theory to a widely used machine-learning step, as well as experimental testing: in collaboration with PI Roos, our collaborator from Finland side, we demonstrated that these techniques can improve the speed of the widely used k-Nearest Neighbors (k-NN) algorithm [Sheth et al., IEEE BigData 2019]. PI Roos developed a fast k-NN algorithm that, at its core, relies on a computationally complex matrix multiplication operation which bottlenecks the speed of computation. This bottleneck was released in this paper by first parallelizing the algorithm, and then tailoring our matrix-multiplication coding techniques  (namely, MatDot codes) to the problem.

This result is also expected to have implications in high-performance computing, which we are pursuing collaboratively with HPC researchers.

3. Outreach+ minority-oriented research: EEG for Coarse and Curly Hair: The minority female student, Arnelle Etienne, designed IoT systems for recording EEGs for people with thick and curly hair common in individuals of African descent, an open problem that has been neglected by scientists, engineers, and clinicians. We are happy to report that this started out as a small effort, but due to encouragement of clinicians, we have succeeded in building some of the first solutions to this problem: novel electrodes and novel hairstyles (leveraging cornrowing, common in the African American culture) that enable reliable recording from this hair type. This problem is extremely important: EEG is the first tool for diagnosing many, many neurological disorders. This work, presented at IEEE EMBC 2018, has led to iincreased involvement of minority undergraduate students in our research, which is a delightful by-product.

Conference organization: The resulting collaborations and interactions led the PI to organize a workshop on Coded Computing at the International Conference on Machine Learning (ICML), bringing together researchers from both information-theory and computer systems (focused on distributed computing), academia and industry, from across the world.

Training: The project trained 2 female PhD students, as well as 4 female and 3 minority students (including two minority females).

Modified by: Pulkit Grover
